yes people are right beta blocker have been relegated to second line therapy when they as drug tehy look at a number of thing the most obvious is how effective they are and side effect but they also look at what they call endpoint these include the adverse health effect of high blood pressure like stroke heart attack kidney failure heart failure and of course death so a drug might lower the bp but have no effect on the endpoint generally drug like ccbs ace inhibitor arb and some diuretic tend to have much more of an effect on preventing or even treating some of these endpoint ccbs are best when hypertension is due to arterial resistance due to stiffness of the arterial wall which naturally increase with age and is more common in afro caribeans there are other issue about the way the drug work or how they might be combined that also influence the drs choice hope this make sense jul http wwwpatientcouk forum discus ccbsorderlatest

by maria graham dizziness is mainly characterized by a feeling of lightheadedness it is a common experience which may indicate either a normal physiological response within the body or a serious medical condition requiring urgent attention most case tend to be the result of normal physiological response danger sign include frequent episode and association with other symptom such a loss of consciousness visual blurring and headache there are a number of toronto dizziness treatment option one may benefit from dizziness should be differentiated form a similar feeling known a vertigo since the two have different cause and treatment your doctor will seek to establish which of the two you suffer from in vertigo affected person will complain that their surrounding is spinning it is very similar to what one experience just after they alight from a merry go round the cause of vertigo is damage to inner ear structure the doctor will also want to establish a number of characteristic of your illness which will provide clue a to the most likely cause these include the factor that trigger the symptom whether or not it ha progressed over time and the severity a physical examination involving all the body system will then be conducted a number of test are vital to establishing the cause of your symptom they include radiological image such a the mri and ct scan and blood test such a the haemogram condition that affect the cardiovascular system frequently cause lightheadedness they include hypertension hypotension heart failure and problem of heart rhythm each condition ha a specific treatment hypertension for instance is treated by lifelong antihypertensive drug and lifestyle modification abnormal rhythm can be corrected by antiarrhythmic drug or fixation of artificial pacemaker heart failure requires long term treatment with antifailure drug the other system that may cause this symptom is the central nervous system there are a wide range of cause that fall under this category they include both chronic and acute condition such a stroke severe headache migraine brain tumor and dementia some of the condition within this system may go undiagnosed for long period of time and it is only after they are greatly advanced that they become obvious fluctuation in blood sugar level is a possible cause of dizziness this is a common problem among person with diabetes in such person the deficiency or loss of sensitivity of insulin make it difficult for the body to maintain the level within the normal limit the problem is likely to be encountered among person that fail to comply with their prescription taking your drug a prescribed will help avoid the frequency of the episode there are numerous other cause of this condition other common cause include anemia and intake of some drug such a tranquilizer and sedative if you take part in a strenuous physical activity by running a marathon for instance dizziness may set in due to physiological change ensure that you have adequate glucose and water to use in such a situation the option of therapy that is chosen for the management of dizziness is greatly determined by the cause when the underlying cause is identified and treated the symptom are likely to resolve or at least reduce in frequency and severity the treatment that are used include avoiding trigger factor in migraine for example using drug and st paul minn chicago satprnewscom st jude medical inc nysestj a global medical device company today announced new data from northwell health highlighting the center experience with the cardiomems hf system the study demonstrated that monitoring pulmonary artery pressure with the cardiomems technology lead to significant improvement in quality of life a measured by the kansa city cardiomyopathy questionnaire kccq and ability to exercise using the six minute walk mw test standard in patient with chronic heart failure these data were presented at the american college of cardiology th annual scientific session the data confirms that patient who are monitored using the cardiomems hf system are seeing significant improvement in the quality of their life including an increase in exercise capacity said dr rita jermyn director congestive heart failure program at north shore university hospital manhasset new york part of northwell health the analysis evaluated patient with new york heart association nyha class iii heart failure underwent implant of the cardiomems device and patient remained on medical management alone quality of life qol wa assessed based on the kccq that measure qol item such a physical and social function symptom and selfefficacy a mw test wa conducted to evaluate exercise capacity for each patient the study found management with the cardiomems device led to a decrease of nearly seven percent in body weight threefold increase in quality of life scoring increase of percent in the distance patient were able to walk within the mw test we are excited to see independent data from center implanting the cardiomems device and are very pleased to see such great result from northwell health said dr philip b adamson medical director and vice president of medical affair for st jude medical the study data confirm benefit originally observed in our landmark champion study which show patient who are monitored with the cardiomems hf system have a reduction in hospitalization and an improvement in their quality of life the cardiomems hf system u a miniature wireless monitoring sensor implanted in the pulmonary artery to directly measure pulmonary artery pressure patient can transmit these data from home to their health care provider allowing provider to stabilize pressure by managing the patient medication more effectively the cardiomems hf system is the first and only fdaapproved heart failure monitor that when used by physician ha been shown to significantly reduce heart failure hospital admission and improve the quality of life in nyha class iii patient longterm prospective data published in the lancet support the effectiveness of the cardiomems hf system at reducing heart failure hospitalization by demonstrating the system can provide physician the opportunity to proactively manage their heart failure patient the champion study originally demonstrated a statistically and clinically significant percent reduction in the rate of heart failure hospitalization at six month and a percent reduction in heart failure hospitalization during an average followup duration of month about st jude medical heart failure business st jude medical heart attack also known a a cardiac infarct coronary occlusion coronary thrombosis or acute myocardial infarction is the most serious form of heart disease it is common for person suddenly affected to drop dead during their normal activity it is essential that you be aware of the symptom of a sudden heart attack today modern treatment is very effective the sooner this is started the greater are the chance of complete recovery the symptom of a heart attack are wellestablished the underlying cause of heart disease have been welldocumented and the way of reducing a heart attack are clearcut and wellestablished much research ha given many answer sensible people will follow the straightforward recommendation offered these are set out at the end of this section it is essential to recognize and provide emergency first aid treatment for a possible heart attack heart attack symptom here are the key heart attack symptom a set out by the national heart foundation a prolonged oppressive pain or unusual discomfort in the centre of the chest behind the breastbone the pain may radiate to the shoulder arm neck or jaw often the pain or discomfort is accompanied by sweating nausea vomiting and shortness of breath may occur sometimes the symptom subside then recur never forget a chest pain that doe not go away after minute of rest should never be ignored it could be a heart attack what to do in the case of a heart attack take immediate action make patient comfortable if conscious sit the person up allay anxiety speak encouraging word call ambulance if possible suggest it may be a heart attack and a special coronarycare ambulance may be available if patient collapse breathing stop or heart stop expired air resuscitation and external cardiac compression must be started if no assistance is available get the patient to the nearest hospital a urgently a possible time may mean a life saved the quicker the patient receives expert attention the more likely are the chance of survival and complete recovery they reduce with the passage of time and no help do not be embarrassed about seeking help it is better to be wrong than make an error of judgment keep calm do not panic a life could depend on your prompt efficient calm manner the symptom of an infarction are extremely variable according to the size of the infarct some are major and can produce sudden death but the majority are smaller and produce a varying range of symptom attack are not necessarily related to exercise a angina is indeed attack may come on while at rest or even during sleep however usually symptom and sign are fairly typical and allow a doctor to make a prompt diagnosis indeed a person affected can often form an accurate diagnosis an important rule of thumb is that it is better to inaccurately selfdiagnose a heart attack than miss it early diagnosis and prompt treatment may be lifesaving no age group is immune from cardiac infarct however they are far more common in male aged year male outnumber female by to it seems that increasing number of younger male are being afflicted with coronary this may be related to the added stress of modern living although others deny this the high level of living with an increase in fat content of food there is a greater cholesterol intake and other factor in recent year the importance of smoking a a cause of heart disease ha become recognized it is now well documented a a leading cause of this disability although the heart may have suffered relatively minor muscle damage the chance of severe and usually fatal change in heart rhythm are about time greater during the first four hour than during the next many heartattack patient believe they have indigestion colic dyspepsia or some other trivial stomach upset many feel embarrassed to make a fuss or summon assistance fearing they are wrong in their belief others deliberately neglect to call help fearing the worst but hoping their inner fear may be wrong each year more than american die from heart attack and disease of the cardiovascular system ie heart and blood vessel system prompt expert treatment can radically reduce a disastrous outcome indeed it is believed that with proper attention per cent of heartattack patient recover and can return to a nearnormal life again heart attack treatment a heart attack is a medical emergency if a person ha any of the symptom enumerated it is imperative to obtain immediate expert medical assistance there is no place for home remedy in these case apart from allaying the anxiety of the patient and making him or her feel more comfortable taking an aspirin can help while awaiting this attention if sudden collapse occurs and the heart stop beating expiredair resuscitation and external cardiac compression will help maintain breathing and circulation if you have had some basic training in this field it is worth commencing and may be lifesaving call an ambulance at once and briefly explain the nature of the symptom if the ambulance is not available get the patient to the nearest hospital a a matter of urgency special mobile intensivecare ambulance fitted to meet cardiac emergency and equipped with highly trained team called paramedic unit are now available in most capital city in australia and new zealand they can often be at the patient side within a few minute and so can initiate lifesaving treatment within only a few moment immediately emergency care ha been administered the patient is then transported to the special coronary care ward or intensive care unit of a major hospital here highly skilled and very specialized treatment with constant supervision is available the patient is usually attached to a constant electrocardiograph machine and a screen reveals a continuous picture of the heart action the relevant test that are needed are carried out quickly treatment is maintained at a high level of efficiency a prompt and accurate diagnosis is made modern test that seek certain chemical called enzyme in the blood assist the expert in pinpointing an accurate diagnosis these are called cardiac enzyme their presence can tell the extent of the heart attack subsequent serial test indicate the progress of the patient death from a coronary is usually due to the failure of the heart to continue pumping adequately or to a breakdown in the nervous control of the heart which lead to a serious condition called ventricular fibrillation newer drug that assist in bringing this condition back to normal are now being used the drug lignocaine xylocaine assist in reinstating a normal heartbeat a large family of medication called the betablockers can also assist in gross heartbeat irregularity a machine called a defibrillator can also help reestablish normal heartbeat activity painrelieving preparation such a morphine oxygen sedation and the medication that have stood the test of time are still widely used for infarct reassurance and supportive measure are a important today a in earlier day when facility for emergency treatment were far le sophisticated than they are now act promptly study have shown that it take the average heart attack victim three hour to do anything about his symptom the average timelapse between the onset of warning symptom and hospital admission is eight hour the first four hour are of paramount importance the earlier a heart attack patient can be admitted to hospital and get expert attention the greater are the chance of survival there are many general measure that the anginal patient can carry out and which may effectively assist in keeping symptom at a minimum level avoiding the known precipitating factor will help immeasurably the patient should make an effort to avoid undue exercise that is known to produce symptom similarly social and environmental predisposing factor must be avoided it is best to avoid circumstance where emotional crisis and flaring temper are involved for this will only breed more and greater problem if allowed to persist it would be best if the patient could adopt a philosophical attitude to life in general accept the position and make the most of the remaining year of life meal of moderate size and easily digestible food preferably low fat in content and free from fried food are best if there is obvious overweight sticking to a kj calorie aday diet for a while will help lower the weight and so diminish the risk factor regular sleep often assist eight hour a night is preferable sometimes with carp onset of the symptom a period of bed rest may be advisable gearing life to meet one ability at coping is essential the same applies to work with due retard to the social and economic circumstance of the individual related post how to recognize a heart attack how to prevent a heart attack risk factor of heart disease heart disease heart failure heart transplant surgery rheumatic heart disease cause of heart disease cogenital heart disorder heart failure symptom jul http wwwhouseandhomeorg heartattack

hi your d need medical care and nutritional stabilization asap if you let u know what part of the world you are in member may be able to advise on the best way of getting your d admitted to a hospital extreme reluctance and refusal of medical care is a common symptom of this terrible illness and different people have managed it in different way from getting large strong relative to sit in the back seat on the way to the hospital to getting medical guardianship it also help to know what youll encounter when you get to the hospital complication from an extremely low bmi like your d can include damage to the structure and function of the heart increased risk of heart failure and death reduction of bone density resulting in brittle bone and breakage muscle loss and weakness severe dehydration which can result in kidney failure edema swelling and a whole host of other terrible thing that you probably know already including heightened risk of suicide i cannot see that treating a symptom at home would in any way be beneficial even if it were possible it would in fact just prolong the time she go without help getting what she really need which is nutrition likely in a hospital her refusal to get treatment is a symptom of the illness it possible to get her in to treatment anyway many here have managed it this forum and the support and information i found here helped save my daughter life while my daughter wa younger when ed struck please know that i like everyone here know how hard and how confusing and terrifying dealing with ed is but that there is hope for treatment and for recovery best wish mar http wwwaroundthedinnertableorg postidpost

a diagram showing how a stem cell in bone marrow becomes different type of blood cell click for credit in a speech john kerry complained about the bush administration saying nothing illustrates this administration antiscience attitude better than george bush cynical decision to limit research on embryonic stem cell during the heat of the stem cell war this wa a common refrain lifesaving treatment could be produced with embryonic stem cell and anyone who questioned whether or not it wa morally acceptable to destroy one life in order to experiment with saving another wa antiscience never mind that there are stem cell in everyones body commonly called adult stem cell and those stem cell also have the potential to cure illness everyone knew that using embryonic stem cell would be better whats the difference between embryonic stem cell and adult stem cell well most of the cell in your body have specific task your skin cell perform one set of task while your muscle cell perform another set of task your liver cell another set of task etc etc these cell have all specialized so they can perform their task efficiently a stem cell by contrast is a cell that hasnt yet specialized it can develop into many different cell depending on your body need embryonic stem cell end up developing into all the cell that make up the body so they are thought to be very very flexible when it come to what they can develop into however to get those stem cell you have to kill the embryo adult stem cell on the other hand have already specialized to some degree for example the drawing at the top of this post show how an adult stem cell found in bone marrow can develop into various different blood cell while that show some serious flexibility bone marrow stem cell dont normally develop into wildly different cell like skin cell a a result it is thought that adult stem cell arent a flexible a embryonic stem cell on the positive side however you dont have to kill anything to get adult stem cell the scientific question then boil down to this is it worth working with stem cell that might not be a flexible a embryonic stem cell in order to avoid killing human embryo those who answered that question with a yes have been routinely labelled antiscience however now that we are year past mr kerrys speech we can see that adult stem cell have in fact demonstrated success in treating a wide variety of illness obviously a lot more research ha to be done and none of these treatment are standard or routine yet nevertheless it is now clear that if there is a limit to the ability of adult stem cell when it come to treating illness we havent reached it yet that brings me to the reason i am writing this article over the past few day i have seen two more example of adult stem cell successfully treating illness the first example appears in jama neurology a specialized publication of the journal of the american medical association this study dealt with the treatment of myasthenia gravis a degenerative neuromuscular disorder that can be lifethreatening the author of the study followed patient that were treated with stem cell from their own bone marrow and all of them achieved stable remission and were freed from ongoing myasthenia gravis therapy now of course this is a small study and while some patient were followed for year others were followed for only year in addition the author note that specialized patient care is necessary for this treatment to be effective a a result they only recommend it for institution that have experience treating patient with myasthenia gravis nevertheless it at least show the potential of using a patient own adult stem cell to treat a neuromuscular disorder the other study isnt a groundbreaking but it doe provide new insight into the use of adult stem cell to treat heart failure the author reported on a randomized doubleblind placebocontrolled study of endstage patient with serious heart failure the only hope such patient have is for a heart transplant since that wasnt possible for these patient they agreed to be part of a study that examined the efficacy of treating their heart failure with once again stem cell from their own bone marrow the procedure typically took only two hour and most patient were released from the hospital the day after the procedure wa done after month those who received the treatment were le likely to have been taken to a hospital and le likely to die than those who received a placebo while those number arent a wonderful a the number in the myasthenia gravis study they are significant in addition the study wa the largest ever done on this kind of treatment thus it clearly show that patient who need a heart transplant have at least one other option thanks to adult stem cell far from being antiscience then caution about using embryonic stem cell is scientifically reasonable adult stem cell have shown quite a lot of promise and they avoid the moral problem associated with killing embryo reference adam bryant et al myasthenia gravis treated with autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation jama neurology doi jamaneurol return to text dr amit n patel et al ixmyelocelt for patient with ischaemic heart failure a prospective randomised doubleblind trial the lancet doi s return to text apr http blogdrwilecom p

sclerosis their family and those who care for them being diagnosed with m can be a very demoralising experience and many people turn to the centre for support the centre provides advice information and practical therapy such a hyperbaric oxygen therapy hydrotherapy physiotherapy counselling body massage and reflexology to name a few specialist clinic and symptom management workshop are also held on a regular basis opened in the centre offer a warm and caring environment for people of all age and their relative and friend it is funded almost entirely by voluntary contribution with m patient study are increasingly hailing the potential health benefit of moderate alcohol consumption particularly when it come to the heart and lifespan but new research suggests many of these study are flawed and that such benefit may be largely overestimated the researcher say we should be skeptical of study reporting the health benefit of moderate drinking lead researcher tim stockwell phd of the centre for addiction research at the university of victoria canada and colleague reached their conclusion by analyzing study that assessed the effect of moderate drinking on longevity they recently published their finding in the journal of study on alcohol and drug according to the national institute on alcohol abuse and alcoholism niaaa over the past month around of adult report engaging in binge drinking and around report engaging in heavy drinking such drinking habit can increase the risk of alcohol use disorder which affect around million adult and adolescent in the u on the other hand numerous study have suggested that in moderation alcohol may be good for u a recent study reported by medical news today for example suggested moderate drinking defined in the study a three to five alcoholic beverage a week may lower the risk of heart attack and heart failure however the new research from stockwell and colleague suggests the result of such study should not be taken at face value after finding that many of them are subject to bias that when accounted for eliminate the reported health benefit of moderate drinking there are many reason to be skeptical from analyzing study that looked at the effect of alcohol consumption on death from all cause the team identified a number of flaw in the way the study were designed one major issue they found wa how the study defined abstainer people who do not drink alcohol the researcher explain that many of the study compared moderate drinker which they define a individual who consume up to two alcoholic beverage daily with current abstainer but these abstainer may include individual of poor health who have stopped drinking a fundamental question is who are these moderate drinker being compared against say stockwell in their analysis the researcher found that only of the study they assessed avoided bias in the abstainer group and these study demonstrated no mortality benefit with moderate drinking furthermore when the researcher accounted for this bias and other flaw they identified related to study design they found that moderate drinker no longer showed any mortality benefit additionally the researcher found that it wa occasional drinker defined a individual who consume le than one alcoholic beverage a week who had the longest lifespan and the team say it is unlikely that alcohol is the reason for this those people would be getting a biologically insignificant dose of alcohol note stockwell the team point out that the research did not investigate how specific type of alcohol such a red wine largely hailed for it health benefit when consumed in moderation wa associated with longevity but stockwell say it is doubtful any health benefit would be down to the alcohol itself overall the team belief their result suggest study hailing the health benefit of moderate drinking should be viewed with caution stockwell say there a general idea out there that alcohol is good for u because thats what you hear reported all the time but there are many reason to be skeptical mar http wwwmedicalnewstodaycom article php

breakthrough cholesterol drug fizzle amid price pushback the associated press posted pm edt updated pm edt washington gtgt when a powerful pair of cholesterollowering drug first hit the market last summer initial excitement in the medical community quickly turned to panic the new drug promised to reduce arteryclogging cholesterol by nearly twice a much a older one but they came at an eyepopping price more than per year compared with roughly for the standard drug some expert predicted a doomsday scenario in which the two injectable drug repatha and praluent would add a staggering billion to the u drug bill a doctor signed up million of patient with elevated cholesterol but then something unexpected happened not much caught between skeptical doctor and costconscious insurer the drug have barely sold sanofi reported a meager million from praluent in the last quarter which it comarkets with regeneron pharmaceutical amgen inc declined to break out repatha sale spending on pricey specialty drug ha doubled over the last five year to billion contributing percent of the growth in u medication spending since according to ims health but the startlingly slow launch of praluent and repatha suggests insurer may have found their own formula for fighting back proofofeffectiveness requirement and rigorous paperwork that limit how many patient ultimately receive highcost drug expert see an escalating feud between drugmakers and insurer with little relief in sight advertisement the company think that their drug is going to save a lot of life and payer tend to be skeptical of those claim somewhere in the middle is the truth say professor darius lakdawalla of the university of southern california generally speaking insurer only cover the cost of the new drug for patient with extremelyhigh cholesterol caused by genetic disorder or those with a history of heart problem and elevated cholesterol the insurance paperwork can run several page and often requires a detailed history of past treatment caught in the middle of the coverage fight are patient who say they desperately need more option to control bad cholesterol or ldl christian jacob take eight medication to manage his cholesterol and related complication including blood thinner for the seven arteryopening stent he received since he ha a rare form of inheritable cholesterol that occurs in roughly one in a million people so he wa shocked when his insurance provider unitedhealth rejected his doctor prescription for repatha i wa floored he said how in the world can we be rejected for a medication that i meet every single standard for jacob said unitedhealth recommended he continue his current drug regimen to see if it lower his cholesterol he is appealing the decision unitedhealth which declined to comment on jacob situation due to patient privacy law said in a statement it u clinical guideline and scientific evidence when making coverage decision these new therapy offer additional ldl cholesterol lowering and outcome study are still pending said the firm recent medical history is littered with oncepromising drug that lowered test result like cholesterol yet failed to actually help patient considering the high price and limited data many doctor favor a go slow approach if youre going to spend that kind of money on a medication then you need to know that it really doing something said dr hal chadow of brookdale university hospital chadow ha successfully prescribed the drug to several highrisk patient but he want to see more research before using them more broadly some of the nation top cardiologist predict the drug will eventually reduce heart attack rate far below level currently seen with statin pill the standardofcare for high cholesterol since the s but study confirming those benefit are still month away a key reason insurer demand extensive documentation before reimbursing the drug i really think it a disservice to the public health to put people in charge of this who are essentially bean counter said dr steven nissen of the cleveland clinic the medical center ha assigned an expert to coach doctor on completing the insurance paperwork industry figure suggest a high bar percent of claim for repatha and praluent were initially rejected in the last quarter of according symphony health a firm that analyzes insurance data the company doing the rejecting say they are merely following prescribing instruction on the medicine which are approved by the food and drug administration dr steve miller of express script the largest pharmacy benefit manager say the company is approving more claim a doctor get better at picking the right patient and making sure they have adequate supporting data wall street continues to bet that the drug known a pcsk inhibitor will become blockbuster eventually while many have slashed shortterm estimate most analyst predict that repatha and praluent will generate combined annual sale of over billion by according to polling by evaluate pharma drug that generate billion or more annually are considered blockbuster the analyst projection depend on one key assumption that followup study show the drug reduce heart attack and death amgen is expected to unveil data from it pivotal study later this year with a similar study from sanofi next year but even assuming those study pan out some expert say the drug which are selfinjected once or twice a month depending on the medication and indication are still overpriced one analysis concluded that pcsk drug represent a low value for patient and said a fairer price would be roughly half the list price or between and per year according to the institute for clinical and economic review sanofi and amgen each criticized the group analysis disagreeing with it method and conclusion the boston nonprofit receives funding from foundation insurer drugmakers and academic institution dr steven pearson the group president say new approach are needed for pricing medicine based on performance he point to another pricey drug launched last summer novartis heart failure drug entresto ha been shown to reduce hospitalization and death more than older drug but it annual price ha slowed uptake novartis ha signed unusual payforperformance contract with several insurer offering partial refund if the drug fails to deliver better outcome pearsons group gave the drug positive mark in an evaluation last year we came out saying good evidence on clinical effectiveness and good value in november amgen announced a similar agreement with harvard pilgrim health care system if repatha doesnt lower patient cholesterol to level seen in company trial harvard pilgrim get a rebate that approach is already used in europe and could become more common here i think pmid nutr metab cardiovasc dis jan epub jan pmid abstract title habitual chocolate consumption and the risk of incident heart failure among healthy men and woman abstract background we aimed to examine the association between chocolate intake and the risk of incident heart failure in a uk general population we conducted a systematic review and metaanalysis to quantify this associationmethods and result we used data from a prospective populationbased study the european prospective investigation into cancer epic norfolk cohort chocolate intake wa quantified based on a food frequency questionnaire obtained at baseline and incident heart failure wa ascertained up to march we supplemented the primary data with a systematic review and metaanalysis of study which evaluated risk of incident heart failure with chocolate consumption a total of participant woman mean age year were included of whom developed heart failure during the follow up mean year total person year year after adjusting for lifestyle and dietary factor we found relative reduction in heart failure incidence in the top up to g d compared to the bottom quintile of chocolate consumption hr ci but the result were no longer significant after controlling for comorbidities hr ci additional adjustment for potential mediator did not attenuate the result further we identified five relevant study including the current study n the pooled result showed nonsignificant relative risk reduction of heart failure incidence with higher chocolate consumption hr ci conclusion our result suggest that higher chocolate intake is not associated with subsequent incident heart failure jun http wwwgreenmedinfocom article pooledresultsshowedrelativeriskreductionheartfailureincidencehighe

description symptom of heart failure click here to watch recent video http wwwyoutubecom watchvszfxhbzh subscribe to our channel for daily update symptom of heart failure heart failure can be ongoing chronic or your condition may start suddenly acute heart failure sign and symptom may include shortness of breath dyspnea when you exert yourself or when you lie down fatigue and weakness swelling edema in your leg ankle and foot rapid or irregular heartbeat reduced ability to exercise persistent cough or wheezing with white or pink bloodtinged phlegm increased need to urinate at night swelling of your abdomen ascites when to see a doctor see your doctor if you think you might be experiencing sign or symptom of heart failure seek emergency treatment if you experience any of the following chest pain fainting or severe weakness rapid or irregular heartbeat associated with shortness of breath chest pain or fainting sudden severe shortness of breath and coughing up pink foamy mucus although these sign and symptom may be due to heart failure there are many other possible cause including other lifethreatening heart and lung condition dont try to diagnose yourself call or your local emergency number for immediate help emergency room health care provider will try to stabilize your condition and determine if your symptom are due to heart failure or something else if you have a diagnosis of heart failure and if any of the symptom suddenly become worse or you develop a new sign or symptom it may mean that existing heart failure is getting worse or not responding to treatment contact your doctor promptly stay update facebook http onfbme qxlb tag published mon apr edt apr http youtubecom watchvslhcsvxkzu

posted mar at pm nanoballs filled with poison wipe out metastatic cancer in mouse for most cancer patient it not the original tumor that pose the greatest risk it the metastasis that invade the lung liver and other tissue now researcher have come up with an approach that trick these spinoff tumor into swallowing poison so far the strategy ha only been tested in mouse where it proved highly effective but the result are promising enough that the researcher are planning to launch clinical trial in cancer patient within a year the new work is very innovative stuff say steven libutti a geneticist and cancer surgeon at the albert einstein college of medicine in new york city who wa not involved in the study the treatment he explains work in three step to place a conventional chemotherapeutic agent near the nucleus or nucleus of a metastatic cancer cell where the drug molecule are most lethal it almost like a multistage rocket that lift astronaut off earth sends them to the moon and return them safely he say at the heart of the new therapy is a chemotherapeutic agent called doxorubicin dox the drug ha been a mainstay of cancer treatment for year a it jam up dna in the cell nucleus and prevents tumor cell from dividing but when it injected into the bloodstream the drug can also kill heart muscle cell and cause heart failure which often force oncologist to either dial back the dose or discontinue it altogether delivering dox only to tumor cell is therefore highly desirable but it ha been a major challenge hoping to provide such cell specificity researcher led by mauro ferrari a nanomedicine expert a well a president and ceo of the houston methodist research institute in texas have spent year developing porous silicon particle a drug carrier the particle micrometerscale size and disklike shape allows them travel unimpeded through normal blood vessel but when they hit blood vessel around tumor which are typically malformed and leaky the particle fall out of the circulation and pool near the tumor that wa step one in delivering chemotherapeutic drug to their target but just filling such particle with dox doesnt do much good ferrari say even if a small amount of the drug find it way inside tumor cell those cell often have membrane protein that act a tiny pump to push the drug back outside the cell before it can do any damage silicon particle act a nanoparticle generator inpg that carry stringlike polymer loaded with a chemotherapy compound called doxorubicin pdox nature biotechnology to get large amount of dox inside the metastatic tumor cell and then past the protein pump ferrari and colleague linked numerous dox molecule to stringlike molecule called polymer they then infused the doxcarrying polymer into their silicon microparticles and injected them into mouse that had been implanted with human metastatic liver and lung tumor a with the previous study the researcher found that the silicon particle congregated in and around tumor site and once there the particle slowly degraded over to week a they did so the silicon particle released the doxcarrying polymer strand in the watery environment around tumor cell the strand coiled up into tiny ball each just nanometer across that size ferrari say is ideal because it the same size a tiny vesicle that are commonly exchanged between neighboring cell a part of their normal chemical communication in this case the doxpolymer ball were readily taken up by tumor cell once there a large fraction wa carried internally away from the doxexporting pump at cell membrane and toward the nucleus ferrari say at this point his team isnt sure exactly why the doxladen ball are ferried toward the nucleus though this is exactly what they wanted not only is the region around the nucleus devoid of doxremoving pump but it typically ha a more acidic environment than near the cell membrane and ferraris team used this to their advantage a well they designed the chemical link between dox molecule and the polymer to dissolve under acidic condition this release the dox at the site where it cell killing potency is highest up to of cancerbearing mouse given the treatment showed no sign of metastatic tumor month later the researcher report today in nature biotechnology in human ferrari say thats equivalent to being cancerfree for year if this research bear out in human and we see even a fraction of this survival time we are still talking about dramatically extending life for many year ferrari say thats essentially providing a cure in a patient population that is now being told there is none the new treatment isnt the first nanomedicine to show promise according to a recent nanotechnology working group study published in the lancet more than nanomedicine compound are now in clinical trial however the new work is promising libutti say because the silicon microparticles tend to target tumor in the liver and lung common destination of metastatic tumor cell the new work hold out hope for improving the effectiveness of other chemotherapy drug a well libutti say there no reason to believe you couldnt make a version of these particle with any chemotherapeutic agent dx idc tnbc age stage grade cm nodeski brca bimx recon t c x jun http forumtnbcfoundationorg nanoparticlesandtnbctopichtml

uab researcher focus on five key area to improve care of cvd patient at am no comment according to the center for disease control and prevention approximately people die of heart disease in the united state every year thats one in every four death the impact of cardiovascular disease is quite large the university of alabama at birmingham is home to many talented investigator who study various aspect of heart disease within the school of medicine division of cardiovascular disease at the comprehensive cardiovascular center and across uab a primary goal of both the division and ccvc is to actively promote innovative interdisciplinary and translational cardiovascular research many distinct yet often complementary basic and clinical study are ongoing at uab with alabama ranking among state with the most heartrelated death this innovative research is providing benefit to patient now and in the future uab researcher are focusing on five key area with an ultimate goal of improving the care of cvd patient heart failure heart failure is a chronic progressive condition in which the heart muscle is unable to function adequately and distribute sufficient oxygen and nutrient to meet the body need in other word the heart cannot maintain it workload multiple researcher at uab are investigating the mechanism by which heart failure occurs a well a searching for way to prevent heart failure and devise improved treatment strategy heart failure can arise a a consequence of ischemic event such a a heart attack indeed heart attack survivor are at increased risk for heart failure development ongoing research is trying to uncover the nature of this relationship during ischemic event the immune system becomes activated which is essential for the repair of the heart however inappropriate activation of immune cell result in chronic inflammation which worsens damage to the heart thereby contributing to heart failure development director of the uab cardiovascular disease division and the ccvc sumanth prabhu md is currently focusing on the role of specific immune cell population in producing heart damage and on finding a way to manipulate immune system so they do not become hyperactivated similarly research in the laboratory of ganesh halade phd is studying novel lipid specie known a resolvins which are able to reverse inflammation in the heart roger white phd and his collaborator gm anantharamaiah phd are exploring the antiinflammatory property of highdensity lipoprotein mimetic compound in atherosclerosis and other disease state other important area of heart failure research involve energetics regeneration cellular survival and remodeling study in the laboratory of min xie md are currently defining whether activation of selfpreservation mechanism such a autophagy promote survival of heart cell thereby attenuating contractile dysfunction following a heart attack in term of remodeling louis dellitalia md is studying the mechanism of extracellular matrix remodeling during heart failure which can lead to stiffening of the heart both xie and dellitalia have identified novel therapeutic target that improve cardiac function in preclinical model heart failure research further extends to the clinic with multiple active clinical study assessing the intramyocardial delivery of mesenchymal stem cell a a novel therapeutic in patient with heart failure genomic determinant of patient response to pharmacological therapy immune cell activation in chronic disease heart failure outcome research using the intermacs registry and testing of novel circulatory support device and other therapeutic in patient with advanced heart failure the study are led by multiple investigator including prabhu salpy pamboukian md jose tallaj md britta brott renzo loyagarendon md and deepak acharya md clinical researcher including massoud leesar md seun alli md and brott are examining interventional approach to ischemic and valvular heart disease and associated cardiomyopathy these include novel strategy for coronary intervention and stent design outcome after percutaneous structural valvular intervention and developing paradigm for adjunctive antiplatelet therapy after interventional procedure nita limdi phd is leading an institutional precision medicine effort to uncover the clinical impact of genomic variation in the metabolism of antiplatelet drug after coronary intervention hypertension research hypertension or high blood pressure typically ha no symptom but can have deadly health consequence if not treated according to the american heart association nearly million u adult have been diagnosed with high blood pressure suzanne oparil md professor of medicine and past president of the american heart association is part of a groundbreaking study called the sprint trial that suggests changing blood pressure guideline could cause the falling death rate from heart attack and stroke to drop even more the trial found that a pressure below wa preferable for highrisk patient a number of hypertension patient are unresponsive to conventional treatment strategy these individual known a resistant hypertensive patient require three or more antihypertension treatment to help manage their blood pressure david calhoun md professor of medicine in the division of cardiovascular disease is a pioneer in translational study designed to identify underlying mechanism causing resistant hypertension a well a in the management of this disease paul muntner vice chair of the uab department of epidemiology in the school of public health recently received a prestigious grant from the american heart association to study hour pattern in blood pressure blood pressure usually decrease during sleep an event termed dipping however in some individual blood pressure doe not decrease during the night this nondipping event is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease the study by muntner and colleague calhoun orlando gutierrez md edward inscho phd oparil david pollock phd jennifer pollock phd and martin young phd is investigating the incidence of nondipping in distinct racial group a well a the potential mechanism leading to this condition related story feb http wwwnewsmedicalnet news uabresearchersfocusonfivekeyareastoimprovecareofcvdpatientsaspx

even casual inspection of a map of the southern hemisphere suggests that the coastline of eastern south america and western africa fit together like the piece of a jigsaw puzzle this same thought occurred to the naturalistexplorer alexander von humboldt who during the early s found similarity between animal and plant fossil in south america and western africa and common element between the mountain range in argentina and south africa subsequent explorer saw similarity between fossil in india and australia in the german geophysicistmeteorologist and polar explorer alfred wegener went a step further and proposed that the present continent were once fused into a single landmass which he called pangaea alllands expanding upon this theory in his book the origin of continent and ocean wegener described how pangaea subsequently split into two supercontinents laurasia corresponding to the presentday northern hemisphere and gondwanaland also called gondwana southern hemisphere an event now thought to have occurred to million year ago wegener could not provide an explanation for continental drift and his concept wa roundly rejected until after his death in from heart failure during an expedition to greenland the occurrence of continental drift wa finally accepted in the s when the concept of plate tectonicsinvolving plate that are in constant motion relative to each other sliding under other plate and pulling apartwas established according to the theory of continental drift a single giant landmass pangaea split into the two supercontinents laurasia northern hemisphere and gondwana southern hemisphere long before continental drift wa acknowledged by the scientific community naturalist were finding ancient fossil of the same or similar plant and animal in continent thousand of mile apart and separated by ocean fossil remains of the tropical fern glossopteris were found in south america africa india and australia while those of the family kannemeyrid a mammallike reptile were uncovered in africa asia and south america by contrast some living plant and animal on different continent are very different from one another for example all the native mammal in australia are marsupial and not placental mammal which suggests that australia split off from gondwanaland before placental mammal evolved feb http knowledgeclassblogspotcom continentaldrifthtml

by scott morgan mount kilimanjaro meter above sea level is one of the tallest in the world the mountain which is found in northern tanzania ha continued to be a popular tourist destination over the year the mountain is a major challenge to conquer and requires adequate mental and physical preparation to increase the chance of succeeding you need to start training for kilimanjaro early at least two month before the hike the type of physical routine that you get involved in should help you build cardiovascular endurance and your muscle strength weight training help you improve your performance and help protect joint such a the ankle knee and the spine which tend to be strained when hiking your target should be to carry a backpack of about pound a you take a flight of stair at a rate of step a minute the amount of training that is required greatly depends on your initial fitness level person that have not hiked before will on average require a longer duration of physical exercise than those that hike regularly beginner are advised to start by walking outdoors for short distance such a a mile and increasing the gradually to say four or five mile take stair a often a possible it is important that you keep consulting with your doctor to ensure that you remain medically fit the doctor will subject you to a full checkup to find out if you have any disease that would make it difficult for you to go for the hike some of the condition that may be a cause for concern include metabolic disorder such a diabetes chronic respiratory condition such a asthma and cardiovascular disorder such a heart failure and hypotension apart from being physically fit you need to also prepare your body physiologically at high altitude the air is thinner and oxygen supply is markedly reduced high altitude training help your body to preacclimatize so that you can cope with such strenuous condition the best way of achieving this is to be involved in several shorter hiking exercise regularly this can be easily done within tanzania where there are a number of smaller mountain near kilimanjaro to be used for practice whether you are a beginner or an experienced climber you need to arrive a few day earlier this will help you relax and shake off the jet lag at the same time it will give you an opportunity to familiarize yourself with the local climate and food there is at least a chance of making it to the peak if you arrive in good time you need to carry with you a number of essential item the technical clothing will typically include hiking pant a long sleeved shirt a waterproof jacket with a hood a pair of glove and sport bra for woman important equipment specific to the exercise include a map a compass or gps sleeping bag and headlamp among others other accessory include a towel toilet paper soap and so on person that are traveling to tanzania need to ensure that they have the proper documentation that will allow them enter the country visa requirement apply to most country outside the commonwealth ensure that you find out in advance what is required for your specific case it would be unfortunate to miss out on the opportunity after week nitinol supera stent in a patient with acute thromboembolic limb ischemia department of cardiology vascular medicine grn hospital weinheim weinheim germany received november accepted april academic editor hiroyuki nakajima copyright tom eisele et al this is an open access article distributed under the creative common attribution license which permit unrestricted use distribution and reproduction in any medium provided the original work is properly cited abstract the treatment of acute thromboembolic limb ischemia includes wellestablished surgical thrombectomy procedure and in recent time also percutaneous rotational thrombectomy using straub rotarex system this modality not only enables efficient treatment of such thrombotic occlusion but also in rare case may imply the risk of perforation of the occluded artery herein we report the case of a perforation of the superficial femoral artery sfa in an elderly female patient with thromboembolic limb ischemia the perforation wa successfully treated by implantation of selfexpanding nitinol supera stent and without the need for implantation of a stent graft introduction peripheral artery disease pad exhibit increasing morbidity and mortality during the last few decade and is estimated to affect over million people worldwide including up to of elderly primary care individual patient with symptomatic pad exhibit a life expectancy of within year of followup whereas patient with critical limb ischemia cli show significant poorer outcome with amputation and death rate of and respectively within the first year after diagnosis especially patient with acute thromboembolic limb ischemia are in high risk of major amputation and death due to sepsis and multiorgan dysfunction such patient are usually older than year and show further comorbidities including atrial fibrillation and history of heart failure the treatment of this limb and lifethreatening condition includes wellestablished surgical thrombectomy procedure and in recent time also percutaneous rotational thrombectomy procedure using straub rotarex system if required in combination with local thrombolysis this method enables quick and efficient treatment of peripheral arterial thromboembolic occlusion despite the low complication rate of rotational thrombectomy perforation of the occluded artery have been reported previously herein we report the case of a perforation of the superficial femoral artery sfa in an elderly female patient with thromboembolic limb ischemia which wa successfully treated by implantation of selfexpanding nitinol supera stent case presentation an yearold female patient wa referred to our department with new onset of severe pain paleness and pulselessness of her left leg since hour duplexsonography revealed thrombotic occlusion of the left common femoral artery cfa figure and the patient wa immediately scheduled for digital subtraction angiography dsa the patient had history of arterial hypertension and heart failure but no history of clinically evident pad dsa confirmed the thrombotic occlusion of the cfa figure a and interventional treatment wa initiated after injection of mg aspirin and iu of heparin after insertion of an guide wire rotarex catheter ab medica gmbh dï¿½sseldorf germany thrombectomy wa performed in the cfa and in the proximal superficial femoral artery sfa figure b resulting in antegrade flow in both sfa but with high remaining thrombotic burden in the cfa figure c and d after repeated rotarex catheter thrombectomy a perforation of the sfa wa noticed which persisted despite prolonged inflation using a mm balloon figure e g due to persistent perforation the implantation of overlapping mm nitinol supera stent abbott vascular illinois usa wa performed which resulted in complete repair of the vascular injury of the sfa figure h and i local lysis wa subsequently performed due to high remaining thrombotic burden of the cfa using mg bolus injection of actilyse recombinant tissue plasminogen activator boehringer ingelheim pharma gmbh ingelheim am rhein germany and continuous infusion of mg h for further hour repeated dsa wa scheduled for the next day in the mean time pain symptom of the patient improved whereas she recovered from paleness of the lower limb except for the area of her distal foot the next day dsa revealed complete resolution of the thrombus in the cfa figure a however reocclusion of the sfa wa unfortunately noticed figure a orange arrow requiring repeated rotarex catheter thrombectomy and implantation of further selfexpanding nitinol innova stent mm and mm boston scientific ratingen germany in the sfa figure b subsequently good angiographic flow wa shown in the sfa and in the popliteal artery with a vessel runoff of the anterior tibial artery figure c f after the second angiographic procedure pain symptom and limb paleness and paresthesia were completely resolved in addition holter monitoring revealed the presence of atrial fibrillation and the patient wa put on treatment with aspirin mg daily clopidogrel mg daily and mg subcutaneous fxainhibitor fondaparinux for week ambulatory duplexsonography at week of followup demonstrated a good triphasic flow pattern in the sfa figure and the patient wa put on treatment with coumadin figure thrombotic occlusion of the left common femoral artery cfa absence of flow can be appreciated in the distal part of the vessel associated with thrombus formation red arrow the origin of a collateral artery can be depicted proximally to the vessel occlusion yellow arrow figure occlusion of the cfa is noticed by dsa a rotarex catheter thrombectomy reestablishes antegrade flow in the cfa and sfa b but thrombotic burden remains high a it can be appreciated by the orange arrow in c mid and distal part of the sfa with thrombus formation can also be appreciated in d after repeated rotarex thrombectomy a perforation of the sfa is noticed with persistent despite prolonged balloon inflation orange arrow in e g subsequently overlapping nitinol supera stent are implanted h resulting in complete cessation of the bleeding complication orange arrow in i figure during the figure triphasic flow in the sfa at week of followup discussion to the best of our knowledge this is the first case reporting the placement of selfexpanding nitinol supera stent for the management of a perforation in a peripheral artery in the past decade significant technical development have occurred with endovascular therapy of acute thromboembolism which offer several advantage over open surgical embolectomy technique for the treatment of peripheral arterial thromboembolic occlusion although the straub rotarex system is widely available and well established for the treatment of such thrombotic lesion perforation of the occluded artery have been described previously and in our case in such case usually stent graft are employed however such stent graft are expensive and are usually deliverable using f sheath this may require an additional arterial puncture under full anticoagulation or lead to additional time spent for changing the arterial sheath which may aggravate bleeding complication in our case the sfa perforation could be successfully treated using selfexpanding nitinol supera stent which are deliverable using a f sheath conclusion herein we report the placement of a selfexpanding nitinol supera stent for the management of a perforation in a peripheral superficial femoral artery further novel option of complication management a described in our case may shift home press release pulmonary hypertension association ph care center program accredits two new center pulmonary hypertension association ph care center program accredits two new center posted on by top news u full feed in press release the pulmonary hypertension association pha ha announced two newly accredited center of comprehensive care ccc a part of the pulmonary hypertension care center phcc initiative program at vanderbilt and aurora st luke medical center join the initiative in care of the other high blood pressure silver spring md prweb march the pulmonary hypertension association pha ha announced two newly accredited center of comprehensive care ccc a part of the pulmonary hypertension care center phcc initiative now found in state in the contiguous united state increased number of cccs provide more option for adult and pediatric patient with pulmonary hypertension ph ph is increased pressure in the blood vessel of the lung that can lead to death from right heart failure common symptom of ph can include shortness of breath fatigue and chest pain the disease is often misdiagnosed and treated a another illness such a asthma or copd delay in diagnosis and treatment cost patient valuable time because patient go month sometimes year believing they have something other than ph the average length of survival for the progressive disease is only year after diagnosis however the good news is that with early and accurate diagnosis ph treatment extend and improve the quality of life for many patient the phcc initiative is designed to create an accreditation program to raise the level of care for patient living with ph criterion are based on key measure of care for ph patient including the program overall commitment to ph patient scope of service provided and expertise of care team the two newly accredited cccs are vanderbilt pulmonary vascular center nashville tenn pulmonary hypertension clinic at aurora st luke medical center milwaukee wi the phcc program help to advance phas mission of extending and improving the life of people living with ph anticipated outcome of the phcc initiative include better informed patient and medical professional improved access to center with expertise in ph and increased opportunity for research collaboration between center phas scientific leadership council slc and the phcc oversight committee set the criterion for phcc accreditation the slc is composed of global leader in the field of pulmonary hypertension including healthcare professional and research scientist in medical center recognized for excellence in care for patient with ph since the launch of the phaaccredited ph care center phcc program a total of center of comprehensive care ccc program have been accredited including adult center and four pediatric center a center are accredited they also agree to contribute to the pulmonary hypertension association registry phar this patient registry will collect data used to evaluate outcome for people living with ph and help researcher learn more about the rare disease leading to the possibility for new breakthrough in treatment and quality of care for more information on phcc go to http wwwphcarecentersorg or email phccphassociationorg about the pulmonary hypertension association headquartered in silver spring md with a growing list of chapter across the country the pulmonary hypertension association pha is the country leading pulmonary hypertension organization it mission is to extend and improve the life of those affected by ph it vision is a world without ph empowered by hope pha achieves this by connecting and working together with the entire ph community of patient family and medical professional among it program pha facilitates more than support group around the country and delivers continuing education for medical professional through pha online university now celebrating it th anniversary pha ha provided more than million in ph research commitment for more information please go to http wwwphassociationorg phassociation on twitter or http wwwfacebookcom pulmonaryhypertensionassociation for the original version on prweb visit http wwwprwebcom release prwebhtm latest news mar http wwwssuchroniclecom pulmonaryhypertensionassociationphcarecentersprogramaccreditstwonewcenters

if you have a problem with stress and keep putting off learning how to deal with it in a healthy way you may be making it easier for cancer to spread throughout your body researcher have found that when mouse are exposed to chronic ongoing stress their lymphatic system undergo physical change that make it quicker and easier for cancer to spread throughout their body and if you have cancer stress is an understatement doctor have a drug that seems to stop this activity and are testing it now on breast cancer patient but seeing how stress physically help tumor progress should be a big wakeup call about how strongly stress may impact other disease or area of your health scientist already knew that stress hormone could increase blood vessel formation giving cancerous cell more potential escape route but until now it wasnt clear whether they also influenced the lymphatic system to test that theory mouse were restrained to create stress the researcher found that the stressedout mouse had a higher rate of cancer spreading than their relaxed peer and were able to show that this wa because the stress hormone adrenaline wa activating the sympathetic nervous system sn to amp up the rate of lymph formation not only that the stress hormone actually physically changed the lymph vessel draining out of tumour allowing cancerous cell to escape to other part of the body faster so not only do you get new freeway out of the tumor but the speed limit is increased and so the tumor cell can flow out of the tumor much more rapidly said erica sloan from monash university in australia the drug that hold promise at slowing spread of cancer from stress is a beta blocker known a propranolol when tracked over about seven year it turned out that those that had been taking betablockers also showed far le evidence of tumor cell moving into the lymph node and then disseminating to other organ like the lung so it provides clinical support for what we see in the mouse sloan told abc there are concern that some betablockers can cause and worsen heart problem even congestive heart failure a decision to use this medication would need to be carefully considered by patient and doctor healthy way to handle stress because we are learning more about the physical affect of stress on disease health and our body through research it may be time to change how we perceive stress for many people it a minor annoyance for others like those suffering with cancer it a huge burden and learning how to handle stress in a healthier way is best done when it doesnt have such a stronghold on you breathing exercise have been used for century by indian yogi to calm the mind relax the body and restore health adopting this daily practice that just take minute a day could have positive health benefit that extend from peace of mind to possibly disease preventing to learn more about using this breathing technique to improve your health click here for a demonstration video http wwwuptodatecom content majorsideeffectsofbetablockers the post control stress control cancer appeared first on easy health option mar http easyhealthoptionscom controlstresscontrolcancer

the medical literature tell u that the most effective way to reduce the risk of heart disease cancer stroke diabetes alzheimers and many more problem are through healthy diet and exercise our body have evolved to move yet we now use the energy in oil instead of muscle to do our work david suzuki canadian academic science broadcaster and environmental activist it been almost three week since paul wa taken my ambulance to mercy hospital er with his heart pounding erratically and two week to the day that he wa released from the hospital after having a catheter ablation to correct atrial flutter click on this link to read that story it been an up and down journey since paul had a procedural followup appointment monday of this week between the ablation and this appointment hed had a couple of bad spell although nothing even remotely close to that which took him to the er in the first place but concerning nonetheless we learned from craig hoffman the physician assistant who saw paul that flutter ablation is about to effective naturally were hoping that paul isnt in the to for whom it ineffective if the flutter procedure ha been successful then what he experiencing when his heart is misbehaving is probably atrial fibrillation but he on a medication for that so after thorough discussion we collectively decided paul should wear a heart monitor for a couple of day to make sure there no flutter and see how frequent and how severe the fibrillation is we learned however that there a third component in the mix sleep apnea also know a obstructive sleep apnea wow wa i ever ignorant about this condition previously i thought well sure you dont want to stop breathing altogether when youre sleeping but if it just a little pause that always pass no harm no foul wrong at the bottom ive included an article from the national institute of health national heart lund and blood institute explaining what sleep apnea is and the danger it pose so paul is going to have a sleep study done in the next few week well figure out what to do from there what is sleep apnea sleep apnea is a common disorder in which you have one or more pause in breathing or shallow breath while you sleep breathing pause can last from a few second to minute they may occur time or more an hour typically normal breathing then start again sometimes with a loud snort or choking sound sleep apnea usually is a chronic ongoing condition that disrupts your sleep when your breathing pause or becomes shallow youll often move out of deep sleep and into light sleep a a result the quality of your sleep is poor which make you tired during the day sleep apnea is a leading cause of excessive daytime sleepiness overview sleep apnea often go undiagnosed doctor usually cant detect the condition during routine office visit also no blood test can help diagnose the condition most people who have sleep apnea dont know they have it because it only occurs during sleep a family member or bed partner might be the first to notice sign of sleep apnea the most common type of sleep apnea is obstructive sleep apnea in this condition the airway collapse or becomes blocked during sleep this cause shallow breathing or breathing pause when you try to breathe any air that squeeze past the blockage can cause loud snoring obstructive sleep apnea is more common in people who are overweight but it can affect anyone for example small child who have enlarged tonsil tissue in their throat may have obstructive sleep apnea central sleep apnea is a le common type of sleep apnea this disorder occurs if the area of your brain that control your breathing doesnt send the correct signal to your breathing muscle a a result youll make no effort to breathe for brief period central sleep apnea can affect anyone however it more common in people who have certain medical condition or use certain medicine central sleep apnea can occur with obstructive sleep apnea or alone snoring typically doesnt happen with central sleep apnea this article mainly focus on obstructive sleep apnea untreated sleep apnea can increase the risk of high blood pressure heart attack stroke obesity and diabetes increase the risk of or worsen heart failure make arrhythmia ahrithmeahs or irregular heartbeat more likely increase the chance of having workrelated or driving accident note from me other research indicates that sleep apnea can also damage the brain the below excerpt is from the sleep foundation researcher have found yet another reason why people with obstructive sleep apnea osa should get tested and treated for the disease according to a recent study published in the journal sleep patient with obstructive sleep apnea syndrome demonstrated reduced brain gray matter concentration gray matter refers to the cerebral cortex where most information processing in the brain take place and here from webmd is how osa cause or is correlated to increased risk here are seven health problem you might face if you have osa high blood pressure if you already have it obstructive sleep apnea can make it worse waking up often during the night can cause your hormone system to go into overdrive which boost your blood pressure level when you cant breathe well in your sleep the level of oxygen in your blood drop which may add to the problem treatment doe make a difference though some people with high bp who get help for sleep apnea can cut back on their blood pressure medication heart disease people with osa are more likely to have heart attack the cause may be low oxygen or the stress of waking up often stroke and atrial fibrillation a problem with the rhythm of your heartbeat are also linked with the condition sleep apnea disrupts how your body take in oxygen which make it hard for your brain to control how blood flow in your artery and the brain itself type diabetes sleep apnea is common among people with this condition up to of them have osa obesity raise a person risk for both disorder although study havent shown a clear link between sleep apnea and type diabetes not getting enough shuteye can keep your body from using insulin properly which lead to diabetes weight gain extra pound raise your chance of getting sleep apnea and the condition also make it harder to slim down when youre overweight you can have fatty deposit in your neck that block breathing at night on the flip side sleep apnea can make your body release more of the hormone ghrelin which make you crave carbs and sweet and when youre tired all the time you might not be able to turn the food you eat into energy a efficiently which can lead to weight gain heart disease people with osa are more likely to have heart attack the cause may be low oxygen or the stress of waking up often stroke and atrial fibrillation kind of heartburn that doesnt get better but many people say that it a problem treating it seems to improve apnea symptom sleep doctor say car accident when you feel groggy that can raise your risk of
